abstract.para: User manual for the &app; screencam application.

sect1.title: Introduction
sect1.para: &app; is a tool that captures movement on a selected area of an X11 screen to files. It does this by taking a configurable number of screenshots per second and saving them either as individual screenshots or as a video. This kind of application, today, is commonly labelled screencam or screencast utility. If fact, one of the oldest of those utilities was Lotus Screencam which served as the inspiration for &app;.

&app; can be used in two distinct modes of operation:
&sf-cap; -- capture individual screenshots to one file each.
&mf-cap; -- capture and encode to video on the fly.

tip.title: Mnemonic
tip.para: The naming of the modes of operation derives from the number of frames that get stored in the output file: One or many.

caution.title: Audio Capture
caution.para: &app; can capture audio, but only in &mf-cap; operation.

sect1.para: Recording in single-frame capture mode may be more convenient if you wish to preprocess the images before encoding, or if you need other video codecs &app; does not support. Individual images can later be encoded with tools like ffmpeg, mencoder, or transcode.
To report a bug or make a suggestion regarding the &app; application or this manual, follow the directions on xvidcap's site at SF.net.

sect2.title: To Start &app;
sect2.para: You can start &app; in the following ways:

listitem.para: Choose Multi-MediaXVidCap.
Execute the following command: xvidcap

sect2.title: When You Start &app;
sect2.para: When you start &app;, the following windows are displayed:
The window with a proper title and buttons is &app;'s main control, while the red rectangle is the selection frame enclosing the area to capture.
The main control contains the following elements:

listitem.para: The Filename Display and Menu displays the current output filename and, if in &mf-cap; mode, the index number of the most recently captured frame in square brackets. In &sf-cap; mode the index number of the current frame will typically be part of the filename.
When in &sf-cap; mode a left click resets the frame count to the start. A right-click while not capturing will pop up the main menu.

The Frame Drop Meter provides an indication of how well your capture session can capture at your desired frame rate. If your system is under heavy load, it may not be able to capture as many frames per second as you wish. This will result in a video that plays back too quickly. &app; displays a green status if you can or can almost capture at the desired frame rate. If you have some frame drop the status turns to yellow, or red if there is excessive frame drop. To reduce frame drop you can capture a smaller part of your screen, select a lower frame rate, quit as many other applications putting stress on your system as possible, or run on a more powerful machine. It may also help to downscale the captured data.
The Stop Button stops a running recording session.
The Pause Button pauses a running or continues a paused recording session. You can also select this before starting to record to start paused.
The Record Button starts a recording session.
The Single Snapshot Button is only active in a paused &sf-cap; mode capturing session. Then it allows you to take individual snapshots on a click of this button.
The Rewind Button has different uses depending on the current capture mode.

In &sf-cap; mode rewinding relates to the index number of the current frame to capture. Imagine you have a stopped capture session that has captured ten PNG images. The filename display may show test-0010.png. You then realize, the last two snapshots weren't what you needed. You can then click the rewind button twice. This changes the filename display to test-0008.png. If you continue to capture, frames eight and nine in images test-0008.png and test-0009.png will be overwritten.

In &mf-cap; mode the rewind button works quite similar. It does not, however, manipulate the index number of the current frame, but rather of the current movie as it relates to the autocontinue feature.
The Forward Button does the opposite of the rewind button in that it increments the current frame's index number or the movie index number depending on capture mode.
The Forward Button does the opposite of the rewind button in that it increments the current frame's index number or the movie index number depending on capture mode.
The Frame Selection Lock makes the capture selection move with the main control if selected. If deselected, the capture selection will stay where it is when the main control moves.
Click the Frame Selector Button to change the area you want to capture. When you click it, the cursor changes to a cross-hair cursor. After that you can either:
click on a single window to capture that window.

caution.title: Moving Captured Windows
caution.para: Note that the area selection is not sticky to the window in the sense that it would follow the window you originally selected, if you move it away. All it does is adjust position and dimension of the selected capture area to match the contents of the window clicked on. If you move the window afterwards, the capture area will stay where it is, unless you have the frame selection lock enabled and manually move the main control to the right position.

listitem.para: click and drag to select an arbitrary portion of the screen.
click on the backdrop to select full-screen capture.

caution.title: Full-Screen Capture
caution.para: With current display sizes, full-screen capture has a very high probability of putting too much stress on your system. Watch the frame drop monitor and possibly adjust your screen resolution if you absolutely must capture full-screen. Remember that DVDs typically contain resolutions of 720 x 486. Capturing full-screen at a resolution of 1400 x 1050 means encoding about 4 times the data rate of a DVD in real time -- not something you will be doing with a pencil and paper.

listitem.para: The Edit Button calls an external program to edit the most recently captured frame in &sf-cap; mode or the current video in &mf-cap; mode. &app; does not provide those applications. By default, &app; calls gimp in &sf-cap; mode and nothing at all in &mf-cap; mode. Both settings can be changed through the preferences dialog.
